summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Christian Everdell and prosecutors regarding redactions to motions in limine (MILs) and a verdict sheet in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The exchange shows disagreement over anonymizing victim names and procedural coordination on filing documents.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney communicating with prosecutors about redactions to motions in limine and a verdict sheet, objecting to anonymizing victim names.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Assistant United States Attorney copied on email correspondence regarding trial document redactions.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on email correspondence about trial document redactions.

connections.description: Communicating about redactions to trial documents, with Everdell as defense attorney and Pagliuca as prosecutor.
Both are defense attorneys copied on correspondence about trial document redactions.

events.title: Prosecutors prepare new redactions version
events.description: Prosecutors inform defense they are preparing a new version of proposed redactions to motions in limine that withdraws some proposals.

events.title: Verdict sheet redlines submitted
events.description: Christian Everdell sends redlined version of verdict sheet to prosecutors as part of trial preparation.

locations.context: Office address for Assistant United States Attorney in Southern District of New York

keyFacts: Defense attorney Christian Everdell objects to anonymizing victim names as 'Minor Victim-X' terminology, arguing there is no need to anonymize them.
Prosecutors express concern about filing documents on ECF (Electronic Case Filing) and wanting to avoid having to redact victim names.
The correspondence shows ongoing negotiation between prosecution and defense about redactions to motions in limine and a verdict sheet in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.
Document references attachments including 'Verdict_Sheet_Govt_Proposed_Defense_Redlines_[2021.10.29].DOCX' showing collaborative editing of trial documents.
The email chain reveals procedural coordination with deadlines, such as prosecutors requesting responses by Thursday at 10 a.m.
